body_html: There's no technical reason why they couldn't provide archives with consistent checksums. The inputs used to create the tarballs are constant for any given commit/tag hash (same timestamps, other metadata and content), so it should be feasible to create archives with consistent hashes. Have we investigated what the actual differences are? Is the compression somehow introducing the variability? Perhaps hashing the uncompressed .tar files would be more reliable?
body_text: There's no technical reason why they couldn't provide archives with consistent checksums. The inputs used to create the tarballs are constant for any given commit/tag hash (same timestamps, other metadata and content), so it should be feasible to create archives with consistent hashes. Have we investigated what the actual differences are? Is the compression somehow introducing the variability? Perhaps hashing the uncompressed .tar files would be more reliable?
body: There's no technical reason why they *couldn't* provide archives with consistent checksums. The inputs used to create the tarballs are constant for any given commit/tag hash (same timestamps, other metadata and content), so it should be feasible to create archives with consistent hashes. Have we investigated what the actual differences *are*? Is the compression somehow introducing the variability? Perhaps hashing the uncompressed .tar files would be more reliable?
